observation: Target company uses AWS as primary cloud provider with $3.38M annual spend, while buyer uses Azure as primary cloud platform
implication: Significant integration complexity requiring either dual cloud management or costly migration of cloud-hosted applications and infrastructure

observation: Target has 2 colocation facilities in Chicago ($748K annual cost) while buyer has 4 data centers including Chicago primary facility
implication: Potential for data center consolidation and cost synergies, but requires careful migration planning to avoid geographic concentration risks

observation: Target has 21 infrastructure staff supporting $4.1M infrastructure spend, while buyer has 101 infrastructure staff supporting larger environment
implication: Target team may lack scale and specialization needed for complex integration, particularly in cloud engineering (only 1 cloud engineer)

observation: Target has hot DR with both sites in Chicago, while buyer has warm DR across multiple geographic regions
implication: Target's DR approach violates geographic separation principles and may not meet buyer's resilience standards, requiring DR architecture redesign

observation: National Mutual uses AWS (us-east-1, $3.4M annual) while Atlantic International uses AWS (us-east-2, $3.9M annual) - same provider but different regions
implication: Regional difference creates network latency and data transfer costs between environments, but same cloud provider simplifies integration compared to multi-cloud scenario

observation: Both companies use Check Point firewalls and Mimecast email security, but differ on SIEM (National Mutual: IBM QRadar vs Atlantic International: Microsoft Sentinel) and MFA (RSA SecurID vs Microsoft Authenticator)
implication: Partial security stack alignment reduces integration complexity for firewalls and email security, but SIEM and MFA consolidation will require migration work

observation: National Mutual has both data centers in Chicago while Atlantic International has geographically diverse facilities (Chicago, Phoenix, Atlanta, New York)
implication: Target's geographic concentration creates integration opportunity to leverage buyer's distributed infrastructure for improved resilience, but may require significant network architecture changes

observation: Target uses Microsoft Entra ID (Azure AD) as primary identity provider, matching buyer's Azure AD environment
implication: Strong identity platform alignment reduces integration complexity and enables faster user onboarding, but RSA SecurID MFA replacement still required

observation: Target operates primarily on AWS (41 accounts, $3.4M annual spend) while buyer is Azure-centric with Microsoft security stack
implication: Significant cloud platform migration or multi-cloud security management required, impacting synergy realization timeline and costs

observation: Target has mature security team (14 FTEs, $2.3M cost) with Splunk SIEM, while buyer uses Microsoft Sentinel
implication: Opportunity for security operations consolidation and cost synergies, but requires SIEM migration and potential team restructuring

observation: Both target (CrowdStrike Falcon) and buyer (CrowdStrike Falcon) use the same EDR platform
implication: Excellent alignment enables rapid endpoint security integration and immediate visibility across combined environment
